awd_titl_txt: Transforming Data Discovery Through Behavior Modeling and Recommendation
awd_abstract_narration:
Social scientists are encouraged to share their data so that their work can be evaluated, replicated, and extended. Open science movements and public funding for science, especially, have increased the number and breadth of datasets that scientists share for reuse and inspection. However, sharing data does not guarantee that it will be found and reused. Search technologies have been enhanced by recommender systems, but they have not been widely applied to research data. A better understanding of how researchers search for existing data is needed in order to design systems to recommend relevant data to researchers. This study will determine if redesigning data search systems to include recommended results can help social scientists discover datasets to reuse effectively. The results of this project will help data archives ensure returns on our national investments in scientific data by increasing data reuse and will promote scientific progress by connecting researchers with relevant data.

The project will a) develop a model of human information behavior that explains how social scientists currently search for data, b) design a prototype data recommender system, and c) evaluate the model and system through field experiments. How data search compares to other information behaviors such as general search is not clear, and this project will explain how data search unfolds. The project also determines whether recommendation systems, popular in fields such as book and movie recommendations, can also work for data and increase their reuse.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to develop a model of human-information behavior to explain how social scientists search for data, design a prototype data recommender system, and evaluate the model and system through field experiments. We experimented with different systems and algorithms for improving data discovery and providing recommendations to researchers looking for data. ICPSR, the world’s largest social science organization, is implementing new data search that incorporates our work. For instance, we identified a language-model-based approach to increasing the relevance of search results to user’s queries. ICPSR is planning to add that algorithm to its existing search options. We created a prototype chatbot that leverages a knowledge graph to provide recommendations to researchers looking for data. Using a knowledge graph instead of word matching to identify search results allows ICPSR to recommend data based on how others have used it, the latent concepts it includes, and the geographies or time periods it covers. We demonstrated the utility of these approaches on social science data and are now embarking on new projects to expand our work to include other domains including general medicine and disease diagnosis. We will also work with ICPSR as they move to turn our proofs-of-concept into production systems. Connecting researchers to existing data ensures that we maximize our returns on investments in science, and it has the potential to increase the speed of scientific innovation. Using existing data reduces the time required for individual research projects.


Last Modified: 03/03/2025
Modified by: Libby Hemphill
